text.p: The following are the main stories from Tuesday morning's German newspapers:
- German association of taxpayers demands that 8 billion mark surplus paid by workers for disability insurance be paid back to contributors.
- Germany tightening visa rules for foreign children in a measure which means that tens of thousands of youngsters born here to Turkish and Yugoslav parents will have to apply for residence permits.
- The bourse upturn continues, DAX rises to 2954 points.
- Unions and SPD oppose government's pension reform plans
- Government wants to cut top tax rate to 35 percent, rather than to 39 percent, from 1999, according to government sources. The lowest tax rate will be cut to under 20 percent.
- Deutsche Telekom share price falls under 30 marks for the first time since it was floated on bourse in November

- Increase in value-added tax has already been planned, Finance Minister Theo Waigel' commission calculating on an two-point increase in the value-added tax to compensate for declines in income tax after tax reform
- Different positions on how to fight unemployment emerge from among parties. SPD favours programme to boost economy, CDU/CSU wants moderate wage increases and overtime cuts.
- Tietmeyer to remain chairman of G-10
- Former Bundesbank president Karl Otto Poehl says that euro could fail
- Economics Minister Guenter Rexrodt (FDP) comes under pressure in the coaltion because of his call to make it easier for employers to fire workers.
- FDP wants to dismantle all rules on shop opening hours.
